revision.text:
{{Infobox Musical | name = Stephen Ward | subtitle = The Scandal That Shook Society | image = Stephen Ward Musical.jpeg | image_size = 250px | music = [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]] | lyrics = [[Don Black (lyricist)|Don Black]]
[[Christopher Hampton]] | book = Don Black
Christopher Hampton | basis = The [[Profumo Affair]] and the life of [[Stephen Ward]] | premiere = {{Start date|df=yes|2013|12|19}} | place = [[Aldwych Theatre]] | productions = 2013 [[West End theatre|West End]] | awards = }} '''''Stephen Ward''''' is a [[musical theatre|musical]] with a book and lyrics by [[Don Black (lyricist)|Don Black]] and [[Christopher Hampton]], with music by [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]].{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-news/9806631/Andrew-Lloyd-Webber-presents-Profumo-scandal-the-West-End-musical.html | title=Andrew Lloyd Webber presents Profumo scandal, the West End musical | publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | work=telegraph.co.uk | date=17 January 2013 | accessdate=28 June 2013}} Based on the real life events behind the 1963 [[Profumo Affair]],{{cite web | url=http://abclocal.go.com/wtvd/story?section=news/entertainment&id=9155226 | title=Lloyd Webber turns political scandal into musical | publisher=[[ABC News]] | date=28 June 2013 | accessdate=28 June 2013}}{{Dead link|date=December 2017}}{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-25405865 | title=Will theatre fans warm to Stephen Ward the musical? | work=[[BBC News]] | date=18 December 2013 | accessdate=26 December 2013}} the musical made its [[West End Theatre|West End]] and world premiere at [[London]]'s [[Aldwych Theatre]] in 2013. ==Background== In February 2012, Webber first revealed in an interview with [[Chris Evans (presenter)|Chris Evans]] that he was considering working on a show based on the [[Profumo Affair]].{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/feb/27/andrew-lloyd-webber-profumo-musical | title=Andrew Lloyd Webber working on Profumo musical | publisher=[[The Guardian]] | work=guardian.co.uk | date=27 February 2012 | accessdate=28 June 2013}} A first reading of the musical was held in [[London]] in early 2013,{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/174053-Andrew-Lloyd-Webber-Will-Present-Reading-of-His-New-Musical-About-Stephen-Ward-and-British-Sex-Scandal-in-London | title=Andrew Lloyd Webber Will Present Reading of His New Musical, About Stephen Ward and British Sex Scandal, in London | publisher=[[Playbill]] | work=playbill.com | date=16 January 2013 | accessdate=28 June 2013}} with its first public outing coming in March,{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/176301-Theme-for-Stephen-Ward-the-First-Music-from-Andrew-Lloyd-Webbers-New-Show-to-Be-Released-March-31 | title="Theme for Stephen Ward," the First Music from Andrew Lloyd Webber's New Show, to Be Released March 31 | publisher=[[Playbill]] | work=playbill.com | date=26 March 2013 | accessdate=28 June 2013}} with Milos Karadaglic{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-features/9955003/Andrew-Lloyd-Webber-My-greatest-regret.html | title=Andrew Lloyd Webber: 'My greatest regret' | publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | work=telegraph.co.uk | date=26 March 2013 | accessdate=28 June 2013}} performing the title song from the show on an [[ITV Network|ITV]] special ''Andrew Lloyd Webber: 40 Musical Years''. The track was later released as a digital download. Officially confirmed on 28 June 2013, producers announced that the initial production would play the [[Aldwych Theatre]],{{cite web | url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/news/profumo-musical-set-for-west-end-29379638.html | title=Profumo musical set for West End | publisher=[[The Belfast Telegraph]] | work=belfasttelegraph.co.uk | date=28 June 2013 | accessdate=28 June 2013}} with tickets going on sale immediately.{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/179597-Andrew-Lloyd-Webbers-Stephen-Ward-Will-Premiere-at-West-Ends-Aldwych-Theatre-in-December | title=Andrew Lloyd Webber's Stephen Ward Will Premiere at West End's Aldwych Theatre in December | publisher=[[Playbill]] | work=playbill.com | date=28 June 2013 | accessdate=28 June 2013}} The show with a budget of £2.5 million{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-news/10531799/Andrew-Lloyd-Webber-I-cant-afford-to-do-many-more-musicals.html | title=I can't afford to do many more musicals | publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | work=telegraph.co.uk | date=20 December 2013 | accessdate=26 December 2013}} has a book with lyrics by [[Don Black (lyricist)|Don Black]] and [[Christopher Hampton]]{{cite web | url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/production/2013/06/andrew-lloyd-webber-musical-stephen-ward-to-open-at-aldwych-theatre-in-december/ | title=Andrew Lloyd Webber musical Stephen Ward to open at Aldwych Theatre in December | publisher=[[The Stage]] | work=thestage.co.uk | date=28 June 2013 | accessdate=28 June 2013}} and is directed by [[Richard Eyre]],{{cite web | url=http://www.news-sentinel.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20130628/ENT/130629627/1009/COLTS | title=Andrew Lloyd Webber turns political scandal into musical | publisher=[[The News-Sentinel]] | work=news-sentinel.com | date=28 June 2013 | accessdate=28 June 2013}} with choreography by [[Stephen Mear]], set design by Rob Howell, lighting design by [[Peter Mumford (Lighting Designer)|Peter Mumford]] and sound by [[Paul Groothuis]]. In 2014, the full libretto of the musical was published by Faber and Faber in book form.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bGaHAgAAQBAJ&redir_esc=y|title=Stephen Ward: A Musical|first1=Christopher|last1=Hampton|first2=Don|last2=Black|date=2 January 2014|publisher=Faber & Faber|via=Google Books}} ==Production history== ===West End (2013)=== ''Stephen Ward'' began previews on 3 December 2013,{{cite web | url=http://playbill.com/news/article/185012-Alexander-Hanson-Is-Stephen-Ward-in-New-Andrew-Lloyd-Webber-Musical-Beginning-Dec-3?tsrc=hph | title=Alexander Hanson Is Stephen Ward in New Andrew Lloyd Webber Musical, Beginning Dec. 3 | publisher=[[Playbill]] | work=playbill.com | date=3 December 2013 | accessdate=3 December 2013}} at the [[Aldwych Theatre]], [[London]], before holding its official opening night on 19 December,{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/06-2013/andrew-lloyd-webber-and-don-blacks-stephen-ward-pr_31154.html | title=Andrew Lloyd Webber and Don Black's Stephen Ward premieres at Aldwych in December | publisher=Whats On Stage | work=whatsonstage.com | date=28 June 2013 | accessdate=28 June 2013}} booking until 1 March.{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/01-2014/lloyd-webbers-stephen-ward-extends-booking-by-thre_33206.html | title=Lloyd Webber's Stephen Ward extends booking by three months | publisher=Whats On Stage | work=whatsonstage.com | date=20 January 2014 | accessdate=20 January 2014}} On 6 September 2013, full casting was announced with Alexander Hanson playing the title role of [[Stephen Ward]],{{cite web | url=http://www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk/news/latest-news/article/item196310/hanson-leads-as-lloyd-webbers-ward/ | title=HANSON LEADS AS LLOYD WEBBER’S WARD | publisher=Official London Theatre | work=officiallondontheatre.co.uk | date=6 September 2013 | accessdate=6 September 2013}} [[Charlotte Spencer (actress)|Charlotte Spencer]] as [[Christine Keeler]],{{cite web | url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/from-mary-poppins-child-star-to-profumo-femme-fatale-in-lloyd-webbers-latest-8802079.html | title=From Mary Poppins child star to Profumo femme fatale in Lloyd Webber’s latest | publisher=[[London Evening Standard]] | work=standard.co.uk | date=6 September 2013 | accessdate=6 September 2013}} [[Joanna Riding]] as [[Valerie Hobson]],{{cite web | url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/production/2013/09/alexander-hanson-joanna-riding-cast-andrew-lloyd-webbers-stephen-ward/ | title=Alexander Hanson and Joanna Riding cast in Andrew Lloyd Webber’s Stephen Ward | publisher=[[The Stage]] | work=thestage.co.uk | date=6 September 2013 | accessdate=6 September 2013}} Charlotte Blackledge as [[Mandy Rice Davies]], [[Anthony Calf]] as [[William Astor, 3rd Viscount Astor|Lord Astor]], [[Daniel Flynn (actor)|Daniel Flynn]] as [[John Profumo]], Ian Conningham as Ivanov, Christopher Howell as Percival Murray, Ricardo Coke Thomas as [[Aloysius Gordon|Lucky Gordon]] and Wayne Robinson as [[Johnny Edgecombe]].{{cite web | url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Charlotte-Spencer-Alexander-Hanson-and-Charlotte-Blackledge-to-Lead-Cast-of-New-Andrew-Lloyd-Webber-Musical-STEPHEN-WARD-20130906 | title=Charlotte Spencer, Alexander Hanson & Charlotte Blackledge to Lead Andrew Lloyd Webber's New Musical STEPHEN WARD | publisher=Broadway World | work=broadwayworld.com | date=6 September 2013 | accessdate=6 September 2013}} Despite initially announcing the production would extend to 31 May,{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/186652-West-Ends-Stephen-Ward-Extends-Booking-Through-May-31 | title=West End's Stephen Ward Extends Booking Through May 31 | publisher=[[Playbill]] | work=playbill.com | date=20 January 2014 | accessdate=24 February 2014}} the show closed on 29 March 2014, the same day as Lloyd Webber's former writing partner [[Tim Rice|Tim Rice's]] show ''[[From Here to Eternity the Musical|From Here to Eternity]]''.{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/news/sir-tim-rice-and-lord-andrew-lloyd-webbers-latest-shows-flop-in-west-end-9152949.html | title=Sir Tim Rice and Lord Andrew Lloyd Webber's latest shows flop in West End | publisher=[[The Independent]] | work=independent.co.uk | date=25 February 2014 | accessdate=5 January 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Official-Andrew-Lloyd-Webbers-STEPHEN-WARD-to-Close-at-the-Aldwych-Theatre-March-29-20140224#.UwvKXv0_v8t | title=Andrew Lloyd Webber's STEPHEN WARD to Close at the Aldwych Theatre, March 29 | publisher=Broadway World | work=broadwayworld.com | date=24 February 2014 | accessdate=24 February 2014}} A typical London performance ran 2hrs 20mins, including one interval.{{cite web | url=http://boxoffice.telegraph.co.uk/tickets/stephen-ward | title=Stephen Ward at the Aldwych Theatre | work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | accessdate=26 December 2013}} ==Music== ===Musical numbers=== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ; Act I 1. The Chamber of Horrors * "Human Sacrifice" - Stephen Ward 2. Murray's Club * "Super Duper Hula Hooper" - Crooner, The Hula girls * "When You Get To Know Me" - Stephen Ward, Christine Keeler 3. Wraysbery * "You're So Very Clever To Have Found This" - Stephen Ward, Christine Keeler 4. The Cottage at Cliveden * "This Side Of The Sky" - Stephen Ward, Christine Keeler 5. Murray's Club * "Super-duper Hula Hooper (Reprise)" - Crooner, The Hula girls° * "Manipulation" - Stephen Ward, Yevgeny Ivanov, Mandy Rice-Davies, Christine Keeler 6.Wimpole Mews * "He Sees Something In Me" - Christine Keeler, Mandy Rice-Davies 7. A Party in Hyde Park Square * "You've Never Had It So Good" - Company 8.The El Rio Cafe in Notting Hill * "Black-hearted Woman" - Lucky Gordon 9. Astor's House in Cliveden * "Mother Russia, While We Can" - Yevgeny Ivanov, Stephen Ward, Christine Keeler 10. Wimpolemews * "Love Nest" - John Profumo, Christine Keeler * "Freedom means the World to Me" - Stephen Ward, Christine Keeler & Mandy Rice-Davies ° * "1963" - Christine Keeler, Mandy Rice-Davies {{col-2}} ; Act II 1. Wimpole Mews * "Human Sacrifice (Reprise)" - Stephen Ward, Christine Keeler, Mandy Rice-Davies ° 2. An Office at the News of the World * "Give Us Something Juicy" - Christine Keeler, Journalists 3. The Dorchester Hotel 4. The Profumo's House in Chester Terrace * "Profumo's House" - Valerie Hobson, John Profumo, Martin Redmayne, Sir Peter Rawlinson, Sir John Hobson 5. House of Commons 6. The Home Secretary's Quarters in the Home Office * "Manipulation (Reprise)" - Henry Brooke, Roger Hollis, Sir John Simpson 7. Marylebone Police Station * "Police Interview" - Christine Keeler, Mandy Rice-Davies, Lucky Gordon, CI Samuel Herbert, D/Sgt Diggs, Vickie Barrett, Ronna Ricardo 8. The Hotel Cipriani, Venice * "I'm Hopeless When It Comes To You" - Valerie Hobson 9. The Arrest * "The Arrest" - Company 10. Court No.1 at the Old Bailey * "The Trial" - Stephen Ward, James Burge, Mervyn Griffith-Jones, Judge 11. Wimpole Mews * "Too Close To The Flame" - Stephen Ward 12. The Chamber of Horrors, Blackpool *Final Scene - Stephen Ward° {{col-end}} {{col-begin}} °Not Released on the Original Cast Recording of the Musical {{col-2}} ==Recordings== A West End original cast album, was released on 30 December 2013,{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/184649-Cast-Album-of-Andrew-Lloyd-Webbers-Stephen-Ward-Will-Be-Released-in-December | title=Cast Album of Andrew Lloyd Webber's Stephen Ward Will Be Released in December | publisher=[[Playbill]] | work=playbill.com | date=20 November 2013 | accessdate=26 December 2013}} featuring nineteen songs.{{cite web | url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2013/12/stephen-ward-cast-recording-released-december-30/ | title=Stephen Ward cast recording to be released on December 30 | publisher=The Stage | work=thestage.co.uk | date=12 December 2013 | accessdate=26 December 2013}} The album released by [[Decca Records]] was originally slated for a March 2014{{cite web | url=http://www.broadway.com/buzz/172220/cast-album-for-andrew-lloyd-webbers-stephen-ward-sets-release-date-free-tracks-available-for-download/ | title=Cast Album for Andrew Lloyd Webber's Stephen Ward Sets Release Date | publisher=Broadway.Com | work=broadway.com | date=7 October 2013 | accessdate=26 December 2013}} release, but was brought forward due to demand.{{cite web | url=http://www.broadway.com/buzz/173244/cast-album-for-andrew-lloyd-webbers-stephen-ward-to-release-early-arrives-december-30/ | title=Cast Album for Andrew Lloyd Webber's Stephen Ward to Release Early, Arrives December 30 | publisher=Broadway.Com | work=broadway.com | date=21 November 2013 | accessdate=26 December 2013}} {{Infobox album | name = Stephen Ward | type = soundtrack | longtype = cast recording | artist = Various | cover = Stephen Ward (Cast Cd).jpg | alt = | released = {{Start date|df=yes|2013|12|30}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = {{duration|m=|s=}} | label = [[Decca Records]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} {{Track listing | collapsed = no | extra_column = | title1 =Human Sacrifice | length1 =5:01 | title2 =Super Duper Hula Hooper | length2 =1:36 | title3 =When You Get To Know Me | length3 =3:23 | title4 =You're So Very Clever To Have Found This | length4 =3:09 | title5 =This Side Of The Sky | length5 =4:33 | title6 =Manipulation | length6 =4:31 | title7 =He Sees Something In Me | length7 =2:05 | title8 =You've Never Had It So Good | length8 =4:41 | title9 =Black-hearted Woman | length9 =2:20 | title10 =Mother Russia, While We Can | length10 =4:12 | title11 =Love Nest | length11 =2:25 | title12 =1963 | length12 =3:47 | title13 =Give Us Something Juicy | length13 =2:47 | title14 =Manipulation (reprise) | length14 =2:13 | title15 = Police Interview | length15 =6:33 | title16 =I'm Hopeless When It Comes To You | length16 =3:45 | title17 =The Arrest | length17 =1:10 | title18 =The Trial | length18 =5:08 | title19 =Too Close To The Flame | length19 =6:29 }} ==Principal roles and cast members== {| class="wikitable sortable" width="60%" |- ! scope="col" | Character ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Original West End actor{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/181822-Casting-Announced-for-World-Premiere-of-Andrew-Lloyd-Webbers-Stephen-Ward-Starring-Alexander-Hanson | title=Casting Announced for World Premiere of Andrew Lloyd Webber's Stephen Ward, Starring Alexander Hanson | publisher=Playbill | work=playbill.com | date=6 September 2013 | accessdate=6 September 2013}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Stephen Ward]] | align="center" colspan="1"|[[Alexander Hanson (actor)|Alexander Hanson]] |- ! scope="row"|[[Christine Keeler]] | align="center" colspan="1"|[[Charlotte Spencer (actress)|Charlotte Spencer]] |- ! scope="row"|[[Mandy Rice-Davies]] | align="center" colspan="1"|Charlotte Blackledge |- ! scope="row"|[[William Astor, 3rd Viscount Astor|Lord Astor]] | align="center" colspan="1"|[[Anthony Calf]] |- ! scope="row"|[[John Profumo]] | align="center" colspan="1"|[[Daniel Flynn (actor)|Daniel Flynn]] |- ! scope="row"|[[Valerie Hobson]] | align="center" colspan="1"|[[Joanna Riding]] |- ! scope="row"|[[Johnny Edgecombe]] | align="center" colspan="1"|Wayne Robinson |- ! scope="row"|[[Yevgeny Ivanov (spy)|Yevgeny Ivanov]] | align="center" colspan="1"|Ian Conningham |- ! scope="row"|[[Aloysius Gordon|Lucky Gordon]] | align="center" colspan="1"|Ricardo Coke Thomas |- ! scope="row"|Percival Murray | align="center" colspan="1"|Christopher Howell |} ==Critical reception== The [[West End theatre|West End]] production of ''Stephen Ward'' received mixed reviews from critics.{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-25462633 | title=Lloyd Webber 'proud' as new musical opens | publisher=[[BBC News]] | work=bbc.co.uk/news | date=20 December 2013 | accessdate=26 December 2013}}{{cite web | url=http://www.bestoftheatre.co.uk/blog/post/stephen-ward-review | title=Stephen Ward Review | work= Best of Theatre| date=22 January 2014 | accessdate=31 January 2014}} ==References== =0-57131-451-1 }} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.stephenwardthemusical.com}} {{Andrew Lloyd Webber}} {{Christopher Hampton}} {{Don Black}} {{Profumo Affair}} [[Category:2013 [[File:The Day the Earth Smiled - PIA17172.jpg|thumb|right|400px|[[Saturn]] in a fully processed [[compositing|composite]] of images taken by ''[[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]]'' on July 19, 2013]] [[File:The Day The Earth Smiled - Preview.jpg|thumb|right|[[Earth]] can be seen as a [[Pale Blue Dot|blue dot]] underneath the [[rings of Saturn]] in this image taken by ''Cassini'' on July 19, 2013.]] [[File:The Faces of 'Wave at Saturn'.jpg|thumb|right|The [[photographic mosaic|photomosaic]] from [[NASA]]'s "Wave at Saturn" campaign. The collage includes some 1,600 photos taken by members of the public on the Day the Earth Smiled.]]
'''The Day the Earth Smiled''' refers to July 19, 2013, the date on which the ''[[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]]'' spacecraft turned to image [[Saturn]], most of its visible [[ring system]], and [[Earth]], during an [[eclipse]] of the [[Sun]]. The spacecraft had done this twice before (in 2006 and 2012) in its previous nine years in [[orbit]]. The name is also used to refer to the activities associated with the event, as well as to the [[photographic mosaic]] created from it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/catalog/PIA17171 |title=Catalog Page for PIA17171 |publisher=[[NASA]]'s [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]}}</ref>
Conceived by the planetary scientist [[Carolyn Porco]], who was the imaging team leader for ''Cassini'', the concept called for the people of the world to reflect on their place in [[Universe|the cosmos]], to marvel at [[life]] on Earth, and, at the time the pictures were taken, to look up and smile in celebration.<ref name=Porco>{{cite news|last=Porco|first=Carolyn|title=NASA's Cassini Cameras to Provide Breathtaking Image of Earth from Saturn|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2013/06/celebrating-saturn.html|accessdate=2 July 2013|newspaper=[[PBS]]|date=18 June 2013}}</ref><ref name=Jones>{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Jonathan|title=People of Earth, say cheese! Nasa to take everyone's picture from space|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/jonathanjonesblog/2013/jun/19/saturn-nasa-earth-picture-cassini|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|date=19 June 2013}}</ref>
The final mosaic from July 19, processed at the Cassini Imaging Central Laboratory for Operations (CICLOPS), was released to the public on November 12, 2013.<ref name=Madrigal>{{cite news|last=Madrigal|first=Alexis|title=The Carl Sagan of Our Time Reprises the 'Pale Blue Dot' Photo of Earth|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2013/11/the-carl-sagan-of-our-time-reprises-the-pale-blue-dot-photo-of-earth/281414/|accessdate=12 November 2013|newspaper=[[The Atlantic]]|date=12 November 2013}}</ref><ref name=Overbye>{{cite news|last=Overbye|first=Dennis|title=The View From Saturn|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/12/science/space/the-view-from-saturn.html|accessdate=12 November 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=12 November 2013}}</ref> ''The Day the Earth Smiled'' photograph includes Earth, Mars, Venus, and many Saturnian moons.<ref name=JPLDES /> A higher-resolution image, which depicts Earth and its [[moon]] as distinct points of light, was taken with the ''Cassini'' narrow-angle camera and was released shortly afterwards.
==Events==
The ''[[Cassini-Huygens|Cassini]]'' probe took images of Earth from close to a billion miles away at 21:27 UTC, July 19, 2013. A number of activities were planned to celebrate the occasion:
* A website was set up as a portal to activities associated with July 19.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Day the Earth Smiled|url=http://thedaytheearthsmiled.com/info.php|accessdate=2 July 2013}}</ref> On it, Porco encouraged the world to celebrate life on planet Earth and humanity's accomplishments in the exploration of the solar system. * [[Astronomers Without Borders]] coordinated events internationally.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Day the Earth Smiled|url=http://www.astronomerswithoutborders.org/projects/the-day-the-earth-smiled.html|publisher=Astronomers Without Borders|accessdate=2 July 2013}}</ref> * [[NASA]] spearheaded a related event called 'Wave at Saturn' "to help acknowledge the historic interplanetary portrait as it is being taken".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/news/newsreleases/newsrelease20040618/|title=Cassini to Take Photo of Earth from Deep Space|publisher=saturn.jpl.nasa.gov|accessdate=2013-06-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622053829/http://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/news/newsreleases/newsrelease20040618/|archivedate=2013-06-22|df=}}</ref> * A "Message to the Milky Way" contest was held by Porco's company, Diamond Sky Productions. People could submit a digital photo taken on July 19 and/or a musical composition. The winning entries were beamed as a message to extraterrestrials, "into the Milky Way from the [[Arecibo Observatory|Arecibo Radio Telescope]] in Puerto Rico".<ref>{{cite web|title=Message to the Milky Way|url=http://diamondskyproductions.com/recent/index.php#mmw}}</ref> This follows the example set in 1974, when the first serious communication to alien civilizations, the [[Arecibo message]], was broadcast from Arecibo.
==Results==
Raw images from ''Cassini'' were received on Earth shortly after the event, and a couple of processed images—a high-resolution image of the Earth and the Moon, and a small portion of the final wide-angle mosaic showing the Earth—were released to the public a few days following the July 19 imaging sequence.<ref name=FoxJuly22>{{cite news|title=Cassini spacecraft photographs Earth from 900 million miles away|url=http://www.foxnews.com/science/2013/07/22/day-earth-smiled/|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=[[Fox News]]|date=22 July 2013}}</ref><ref name=Spinks>{{cite news|last=Spinks|first=Peter|title=Earth viewed from a billion miles away|url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/sci-tech/earth-viewed-from-a-billion-miles-away-20130726-2qo22.html|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald|date=26 July 2013}}</ref>
Processing of the full mosaic took place at CICLOPS under Porco's direction over the course of approximately two months.<ref name=PorcoNov12>{{cite news|last=Porco|first=Carolyn|title=Viewpoint: Saturn snapped as Earth smiled|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-24913141|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=12 November 2013}}</ref> During the four hours it took ''Cassini'' to image the entire 404,880-mile-wide scene, the spacecraft captured a total of 323 images, 141 of which were used in the mosaic.<ref name=JPLDES>{{cite web|title=The Day the Earth Smiled|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/spaceimages/details.php?id=PIA17172|publisher=NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory|accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref> NASA revealed that this imaging marked the first time four planets – Saturn, Earth, Mars, and Venus – had been captured at once in visible light by the ''Cassini'' craft.<ref name=Hotz>{{cite news|last=Hotz|first=David Lee|title=Saturn from the Dark Side|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/photojournal/2013/11/13/saturn-from-the-dark-side/|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=13 November 2013}}</ref> It was also the first time the people of Earth knew in advance that their picture would be taken from the outer solar system.<ref name=Jones />
NASA's official release of the final ''The Day the Earth Smiled'' mosaic on November 12, 2013 was met with much fanfare in news media outlets around the world.<ref name=Madrigal/><ref name=Boyle>{{cite news|last=Boyle|first=Alan|title=Planets galore! Saturn probe's big pic finally unveiled|url=http://photoblog.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/11/12/21423806-planets-galore-saturn-probes-big-pic-finally-unveiled|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=[[NBC News]]|date=12 November 2013}}</ref><ref name=Overbye/><ref name=ElMundo>{{cite news|title=La Tierra, un punto azul diminuto tras los anillos de Saturno|url=http://www.elmundo.es/ciencia/2013/11/13/528355f80ab740b4358b456b.html|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=El Mundo|date=13 November 2013}}</ref><ref name=Page>{{cite news|last=Page|first=Lewis|title=SPACE, the FINAL FRONTIER: These are the images of the star probe Cassini|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/11/13/space_the_final_frontier_these_are_the_images_of_the_star_probe_cassini/|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=[[The Register]]|date=13 November 2013}}</ref> The image graced the front page of ''The New York Times'' the following day.<ref name=LouisS>{{cite tweet|user=LouisS|author=Louis Suarato|number=400648502314680320|date=13 November 2013|title=Saturn and astronomy make the front page of the New York Times.}}</ref><ref name="NYTcover">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/images/2013/11/13/nytfrontpage/scan.pdf|title=Saturn and Its Rings, a Wide View|date=13 November 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> Public figures including media producer [[Seth MacFarlane]] lauded the image.<ref name=MacFarlane>{{cite tweet|user=SethMacFarlane|author=Seth MacFarlane|number=400675296887578624|date=13 November 2013|title=Brand new stunning photograph of Saturn, taken by NASA's Cassini spacecraft}}</ref> The mosaic was also presented by Carolyn Porco, and dedicated to the late astronomer [[Carl Sagan]], at a ceremony at the [[Library of Congress]] in honor of its acquisition of Sagan's papers.<ref name=Allen>{{cite news|last=Allen|first=Erin|title=Portraits of the Solar System: Talking with Carolyn Porco About Carl Sagan|url=http://blogs.loc.gov/loc/2013/11/portraits-of-the-solar-system-talking-with-carolyn-porco-about-carl-sagan/|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=The Library of Congress Blog|date=14 November 2013}}</ref> In addition, a collage of images submitted by 1,600 members of the public to NASA's Wave at Saturn campaign was released on November 12.<ref name=JPLWave>{{cite web|title=The Faces of 'Wave at Saturn'|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/cassini/multimedia/jpl/pia17679.html#.UoV1uY3pUXx|publisher=NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory|accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref>
== See also == * ''[[The Blue Marble]]'' * [[Earth Anthem]] * [[Earth Day]] * ''[[Earthrise]]'' * ''[[Pale Blue Dot]]'' * [[Family Portrait (MESSENGER)|''Solar System Family Portrait'']]

{{Infobox television | show_name = The New Three Stooges | image = New3stoogestheme.JPEG | caption = | runtime = 5 minutes | creator = [[Norman Maurer]]
Dick Brown | producer = Norman Maurer
Lee Orgel | director = [[Edward Bernds]] | starring = [[Moe Howard]]
[[Larry Fine]]
[[Joe DeRita]]
[[Emil Sitka]]
[[Jeff Maurer]]
Peggy Brown
[[Margaret Kerry]]
[[Tiny Brauer]]
[[Paul Frees]]
[[Hal Smith (actor)|Hal Smith]] | narrated = | composer = | country = United States | language = English | network = [[Broadcast syndication|Syndicated]] | first_aired = October 1965 | last_aired = September 1966 | preceded_by = [[The Three Stooges]] | followed_by = ''[[The Robonic Stooges]]'' | num_seasons = | num_episodes = 156 individual cartoons | company = Normandy Productions
[[Cambria Productions|Cambria Studios]]
Heritage Productions }} '''''The New Three Stooges''''' is an American animated television series that ran from 1965 to 1966 starring [[the Three Stooges]]. The show follows the trio's antics both in live-action and animated segments. The cast consisted of [[Moe Howard]], [[Larry Fine]] and [[Joe DeRita|Joe "Curly Joe" DeRita]], with actor and close friend [[Emil Sitka]] co-starring, as well as [[Margaret Kerry]]. ==Production== 41 live action sequences were executively produced by cartoonist [[Norman Maurer]], Moe's son-in-law, who was their film agent at this time. [[Edward Bernds]], who had directed the team at Columbia Pictures from 1945 to 1952 during most of the [[Shemp Howard|Shemp]] era, was also hired to write and direct the series. Emil Sitka, who had appeared in many of the Stooges comedies over the years, was slated to appear in these wraparounds as straightman to the Stooges.{{cite book| last = Howard Maurer| first = Joan| authorlink = Joan Howard Maurer|author2=Jeff Lenburg |author3=Greg Lenburg | title = The Three Stooges Scrapbook| publisher = Citadel Press| year = 1982| location = | pages = 170–171| doi =| id = | isbn = 0-8065-0946-5}} [[Cambria Productions|Cambria Studios]] produced 156 short Stooge cartoons under the supervision of Lee Orgel. Four cartoons were produced to correspond thematically with 40 of the live-action Stooge opening and closing sequences, so that one live-action sequence could serve as a wraparound for four different cartoons. Joe DeRita later commented that this presented something of a problem for viewers: {{cquote|There were 156 cartoons and we made only 40 live-action segments. So after they ran the whole 40, they'd just start over by using these same introductions on ''new'' cartoons. This turned out to be misleading because viewers would say, 'Oh, I've seen this one before.' and they'd turn off the television. They didn't know it was a new cartoon.}} Most of the cartoons ended up with the trio running into the horizon after accidentally causing havoc at their current jobs. The cartoons were unusual for Cambria in that they did not use [[Syncro-Vox]], Cambria's patented technique which used filmed footage of the voice actors' mouths over top of still frames. The pilot cartoon, "That Little Old Bomb Maker", featured a unique live-action wrap around that was not reused on other cartoons. Some of the cartoons featured a recurring character named Badman, a jerky supervillain with a [[Batman]] get-up who is actually a 5-year-old boy that is nice and kind. The boy can only transform to Badman if he ever hears or says the word "bad", and for Badman, vice versa for "good". In the episode "Badman of the Briny", the two finally find out that they are the same person in several scenes. Another recurring character was a western outlaw named Getoutoftownbysundown Brown. To avoid any licensing problems, Cambria did not use any of the past Three Stooges theme songs, including "[[Three Blind Mice]]", or "[[Listen to the Mockingbird]]", even though both had lapsed into the [[public domain]] at the time (likewise, the on-screen title used a numeral 3 to avoid infringing on any trademark [[Columbia Pictures]] might have held on the phrase "The Three Stooges"). Several of the musical pieces used on the show were also used for the ''[[Bozo's Big Top]]'' series in the 1960s and early 1970s.{{Citation needed|date=September 2012}} This was actually not the first attempt at an animated version of "The Three Stooges", nor was it the last. During the late 1950s, [[Norman Maurer]] attempted to sell ''Stooge Time'', a partially live action, partially [[rotoscoping|rotoscope animation]] half-hour series to television. In 1960, Maurer and the Stooges filmed a pilot for a half-hour series ''[[The Three Stooges Scrapbook]]'', which featured a five-minute Stooge cartoon. The Three Stooges would later return to animated form in two episodes of ''[[The New Scooby-Doo Movies]]'' and in the series ''[[The Robonic Stooges]]''. ==Reception== ''The New Three Stooges'' was well received upon initial airings, despite the use of [[limited animation]]. However, the boys were visibly aging during this time (Moe was 68 and Larry was 63), so the [[slapstick]] was subdued in the live action segments. Orgel later stated that the Stooges' penchant for slapstick violence was kept to a minimum due to the concerns of parental groups. In addition, Larry's health was in decline, resulting in several lines of dialogue being slurred. This resulted in much of the comedy being divided between Moe and Curly Joe, with Larry only chiming in when necessary.{{cite book| last = Forrester| first = Jeff| authorlink = Jeff Forrester| title = The Three Stooges: The Triumphs and Tragedies of the Most Popular Comedy Team of All Time| publisher = Donaldson Books| year = 2004| pages = 162| url = | doi =| id = | isbn = 0-9715801-0-3}} The color television series lasted successfully from 1965 to 1966. Although animated portions of the show were last aired in [[Television syndication|syndication]] on [[WGN-TV]] in the [[Chicago]] area in the early 1980s (and later the early 1990s), repackaged and distributed at the time by [[Harmony Gold USA]] and Jeffrey Scott Productions,[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cUmIMeqNfKQ New 3 Stooges – Syndicated Program Elements, Circa 1984 – YouTube], accessed on January 26, 2013. it is occasionally seen on [[Me-TV]]. It also aired in Japan on TV Tokyo. Several episodes are currently available on [[VHS]] and [[DVD]] (often in cheap "dollar packages") because the majority of the series fell into the [[public domain]]. An example of an episode that is not in the public domain is "The Tree Nuts". ''The New Three Stooges '' became the only regularly scheduled television series in the Stooges' history. Unlike other film shorts that aired on television like ''[[Looney Tunes]]'', ''[[Tom and Jerry]]'' and ''[[Popeye the Sailor (animated cartoons)|Popeye]]'', the Stooges' short films never had a regularly scheduled national television program to air in, neither on network nor syndicated; the film shorts, at roughly 20 minutes apiece, were of ideal size to be run as a stand-alone television series in and of themselves. When Columbia/Screen Gems licensed the film library to television beginning in 1958, local stations aired the shorts when they saw fit, either as late-night "filler" or marathon sessions. On October 15, 2013, [[Image Entertainment|Image Madacy Entertainment]] released ''The New Three Stooges: Complete Cartoon Collection'' on DVD in Region 1 for the very first time.{{cite web |url=http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/New-Stooges-Complete-Cartoon-Collection/18642 |title=The New Three Stooges DVD news: Announcement for The New Three Stooges – Complete Cartoon Collection |publisher=tvshowsondvd.com |accessdate=September 7, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304203725/http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/New-Stooges-Complete-Cartoon-Collection/18642 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |df= }} The five-disc set features all 156 cartoons and 40 live action sequences on four discs and the bonus disc is a CD by the Stooges. ==Lawsuit== The series proved to be a financial headache for the Stooges. In accordance with their contract, Cambria Studios' distributor was supposed to forward quarterly statements to the trio to keep them abreast of the show's profits. Norman Maurer recalled receiving only one or two statements over a five-year period, ultimately leading to a lawsuit. The judge presiding over the case knew little about the film or television industry and ruled in favor of Cambria. The Stooges appealed the decision in 1975, leading to a victory in their favor. However, it changed nothing in regard to the distributor's failure to provide the necessary profit statements to Normandy Productions, and by the time the case was decided, both Larry and Moe had died. ==Episodes== List of live-action [[Wraparound program|wraparounds]] and cartoons for ''The New Three Stooges'' television series (1965-1966): ===Live-action wraparounds for ''Three Stooges'' episodes===
*Soldiers *Lost *Campers *[[Bakers]] *Zookeepers *Flat Tire *Fan Belt *Fishermen *[[Dentist]] (remake of ''[[The Tooth Will Out]]'' (1951)) *Janitors *Artists *Decorators (remake of ''[[A Bird in the Head]]'' (1946)/''[[Jerks of All Trades]]'' (1949)) *Golfers (remake of ''[[Three Little Beers]]'' (1935)) *Hunters *Weighing In *Telegram *Buried Treasure *Outdoor Breakfast *Setting Up Camp *Rare Bird *Caretakers
*Seasick Joe *Electricians (remake of ''[[They Stooge to Conga]]'' (1943)) *Salesmen *Barbers *Prospectors *Sweepstakes Ticket *Sunbathers *Inheritance *Melodrama *Waiters *Athletes *Doctors *Shipmates *High Voltage (remake of ''[[Monkey Businessmen]]'' (1946)) *Pilots *Turkey Stuffers *Piemakers *Sharpshooter *Magicians

{{clear}} == Program credits == *A Cambria-Normandy Production *Executive Producer – Dick Brown *Associate Producer – [[David Detiege]] *Executive Producer – Live Action – [[Norman Maurer]] *Supervisor of Production – Lee Orgel *Stories and Storyboards – Jack Miller, Sam Cornell, Art Diamond, [[Warren Tufts]], Cecil Beard, [[Lee Orgel]], [[David Detiege|Dave Detiege]], Barbara Chain, Jack Kinney, Nick George, Pat Kearin, Homer Brightman *Direction – [[Edward Bernds|Eddie Bernds]], Eddie Rehberg, Sam Cornell, [[David Detiege|Dave Detiege]] *Animation – Chick Otterstrom, Kay Wright, Bob Maxfield *Layouts – Dan Noonan, Hi Mankin, Nick Panesis, Lee Mishkin *Backgrounds – Gloria Woods, Bob Inman, Bill Butler *Production Managers – Fred Darley, Cliff Selkirk *Music department – [[Paul Horn (jazz musician)|Paul Horn]] (original music); Darrell Calker, Walter Greene, Al Sack, Hans J. Salter, [[Lee Zahler]] (stock music); [[Gordon Zahler]] (supervisor) *Painting – Connie Crawley *Camera – Jerry Smith, [[Edwin Gillette|Ed Gillette]] *Editing – William J. Faris, George Probert *Cast (Live Action) – [[Moe Howard]], [[Larry Fine]], [[Joe DeRita]], [[Emil Sitka]], [[Margaret Kerry]] (aka Mrs. Dick Brown), [[Jeffrey Maurer]], [[Cary Brown]], [[Tina Brown]], [[Eileen Brown]], and [[Bill Brauer]] ("Soldiers" only) *Cast (Voices) – Moe Howard, Larry Fine, Curly Joe DeRita, Margaret Kerry, [[Hal Smith (actor)|Hal Smith]], [[Johnny Coons]], and [[Paul Frees]] ("That Little Old Bomb Maker" only) ==Home media== Using the original 16mm acetates, [[Rhino Entertainment]] issued a restored version of the majority of the series on [[DVD]] in 2002.[http://amzn.com/B00005UM36 ''The Three Stooges – Cartoon Classics, Vol. 1''] In 2004, EastWest DVD released a slim case volume of episodes. In 2007 and 2008, [[Mill Creek Entertainment]] released a number of episodes as part of their ''Ultimate 150 Cartoon Festival'', their ''Giant 600 Cartoon Collection'' and their ''200 Classic Cartoons – Collector's Edition Label'' formats. ==See also== *''[[The Three Stooges Scrapbook]]'' *''[[The Robonic Stooges]]'' *''[[The New Scooby-Doo Movies]]'' *''[[Laurel and Hardy (animated series)|Laurel and Hardy]]'' *''[[The Abbott and Costello Cartoon Show]]'' *''[[Hoppity Hooper]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0058832|title=The New Three Stooges}} *{{tv.com show|the-new-three-stooges|The New Three Stooges}} *{{Internet Archive film clip|ColorCrazinessTheThreeStooges|The New 3 Stooges live-action segments}} {{ThreeStooges}} {{DEFAULTSORT:New Three Stooges, The}} [[Category:Cultural depictions of The Three Stooges]] [[Category:1965 American television series debuts]] [[Category:1966 American television series endings]] [[Category:American children's animated comedy television series]] [[Category:1960s American animated television series]] [[Category:First-run syndicated television programs in the United States]] [[Category:Television programs based on films]] [[Category:Animation based on real people]] [[Category:American television series with live action and animation]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox restaurant | name = The Shed at Dulwich | image = | image_width = | image_alt = | image_caption = | pushpin_map = United Kingdom London | map_caption = | established = | current-owner = Oobah Butler<ref name=ES/> | chef = | head-chef = | food-type = | dress-code = | rating = 1st in London on [[TripAdvisor]]<ref name=ES/> | street-address = Friern Road, SE22 0BB | city = London | country = UK | postcode = | coordinates = {{coord|51.45|-0.07|display=inline,title}} | website = {{URL|https://www.theshedatdulwich.com/}} }} '''The Shed at Dulwich''' was a spoof restaurant in a [[garden shed]] in [[Dulwich]]. It was created as a hoax by journalist Oobah Butler for [[Vice (magazine)|Vice magazine]] and became the top-rated restaurant in London on [[TripAdvisor]] before the listing was taken down.<ref name=T/> The restaurant was open for one night in November 2017, serving ten guests including a couple from California.<ref name=ES/>
The faux menu theme was "moods”<ref name=DT/>, and Butler photographed plates of food created using household products including shaving foam and [[dishwasher tablet]]s.<ref name="ny">{{cite news |title=The Never-Ending War on Fake Reviews |url=https://www.newyorker.com/tech/elements/the-never-ending-war-on-fake-reviews |accessdate=1 June 2018 |work=The New Yorker |date=31 May 2018}}</ref> One item on the menu purported to be "[[Empathetic]] Vegan clams in a clear broth with parsnips, carrots, celery, and potatoes. Served with rye crisps."<ref name=DT/>
Butler had once worked posting fake reviews of other restaurants at a rate of £10 per review, saying, "I’d look at the menu, pick something, and start lying." For The Shed, he asked friends to post fake TripAdvisor reviews<ref name="vice">{{cite web |title=I Made My Shed the Top Rated Restaurant On TripAdvisor |url=https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/434gqw/i-made-my-shed-the-top-rated-restaurant-on-tripadvisor |website=Vice |accessdate=1 June 2018 |language=en-uk |date=6 December 2017}}</ref> in sufficient quantity to place the venue among the top two thousand restaurants in London.<ref name="ny"/> The restaurant attracted a single one-star review from what Butler assumed was a rival.<ref name="ny"/>
After becoming the top-rated restaurant on TripAdvisor and bombarded with requests for bookings, Butler staged a genuine opening night for the restaurant, serving thinly-disguised £1 [[ready meal]]s to ten customers.<ref name=ES/><ref name="vice"/> Having been blindfolded and then led down the alley past his house to the end of the garden and the shed, some said they wanted to come back and would recommend it.<ref name="vice"/>
The hoax drew comparison to the trend for [[micro-restaurant]]s. In 2017 chef [[Tom Kerridge]] started a real venue called ''The Shed'', opposite his gastropub, [[The Hand and Flowers]], in [[Marlow, Buckinghamshire|Marlow]], which was described as an "intimate private dining space".<ref name=T18/>
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=ES>{{citation |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/dulwich-shed-becomes-tripadvisors-number-one-ranked-restaurant-in-london-after-fake-reviews-a3712606.html |newspaper=Evening Standard |title=Writer 'tricks' TripAdvisor into making his Dulwich shed number one ranked restaurant in London |author=Patrick Grafton-Green |date=7 December 2017}}</ref> <ref name=T>{{citation |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/prankster-oobah-butler-cooks-up-top-restaurant-the-shed-at-dulwich-fx6hfwj89 |newspaper=The Times |title=Prankster Oobah Butler tricks TripAdvisor into thinking his shed is London’s best restaurant |date=7 December 2017 |author=Valentine Low}}</ref> <ref name=DT>{{citation |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/12/06/garden-becomes-top-rated-london-restaurant-tripadvisor-site/ |newspaper=Daily Telegraph |title=Garden shed becomes top-rated London restaurant on TripAdvisor after site tricked by fake reviews |author= Helena Horton |date=6 December 2017}}</ref> <ref name=T18>{{citation |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/from-evelyns-table-to-tom-kerridges-shed-the-rise-of-the-micro-restaurant-w06q87nln |newspaper=The Times |title=From Evelyn’s Table to Tom Kerridge’s Shed: the rise of the micro-restaurant |author=Harry Wallop |date=11 January 2018}}</ref> }}
==External links== * [https://archive.today/20171204115313/https://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Restaurant_Review-g186338-d12396027-Reviews-The_Shed_At_Dulwich-London_England.html Listing on TripAdvisor], archived on 4 December 2017 * {{cite web|url=http://www.dulwichsociety.com/2017-autumn/1543-restaurants-in-dulwich-and-tripadvisor|title=Restaurants in Dulwich and TripAdvisor|work=The Dulwich Society|date=28 September 2017}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20171105232729/https://www.tripadvisor.com/Restaurants-g186338-London_England.html Tripadvisor London restaurant page, listing The Shed at Dulwich as rated #1 of 18,101 reaturants in London], archive of 5 November 2017
[[Category:2017 hoaxes]] [[Category:Restaurants in London]] [[Category:Hoaxes in England]] [[Category:Dulwich]] [[Category:Journalistic hoaxes]] [[Category:TripAdvisor]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Shed Dulwich}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta4)
revision.text:
{{Primary sources|date=November 2009}} [[File:Waltic e-post.gif|thumb|alt=WALTIC logotype.|The '''WALTIC''' logotype.]]
'''WALTIC''' (''Writers’ and Literary Translators’ International Congress'') - "The Value of Words", is a bi-annual international literary congress founded and owned by '''The Swedish Writers’ Union'''. Having its premier launch in [[Stockholm]] between 29 June and 2 July 2008, WALTIC’s aim and thematic scope is divided in accordance to three key elements: ''Increase literacy'', ''Safeguard freedom of expression'', and ''Strengthen authors’ rights''.
WALTIC 2008 keynote speakers were [[Mia Couto]] and [[Nawal El-Saadawi]]. Among the invited speakers present were [[Türker Armaner]], [[Antonia Arslan]], [[Yusuf Azemoun]], [[Karin Barber]], [[Ann Louise Bardach]], [[Abdelkader Benali]], [[Charles Bernstein]], [[Calixthe Beyala]], [[Giannina Braschi]], [[David Brookshaw]], [[Mircea Cărtărescu]], [[Mauro Covacich]], [[Tsitsi Dangarembga]], [[Assia Djebar]], [[Gamal el-Ghitany]], [[Horace Engdahl]], [[James English (writer)|James English]], [[Filip Florian]], [[Jean-Claude Guédon]], [[Josef Haslinger]], [[Rafael Hernández (writer)|Rafael Hernández]], [[Ho Anh Thai]], [[Uzodinma Iweala]], [[Clara Janés]], [[Eileen Julien]], [[Jonas Hassen Khemiri]], [[Jamaica Kincaid]], [[Antije Krog]], [[Leevi Lehto]], [[Eileen Julien]], [[Henning Mankell]], [[Ana Menendez]], [[Gcina Mhlope]], [[Rosa Montero]], [[Bharati Mukherjee]], [[Herta Müller]], [[Simone Murray]], [[Sonia Nimr]], [[Saliha Paker]], [[Elena Poniatowska]], [[Philip Pullman]], [[Laura Restrepo]], [[Rodrigo Rey Rosa]], [[Hans Rosling]], [[Alfian Bin Sa’at]], [[Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak]], [[Dava Sobel]], [[Muniz Sodré]], [[Saša Stanišic]], [[Krister Stoor]], [[Farzaneh Taheri]], [[Shaun Tan]], [[Yoko Tawada]], [[Dubravka Ugrešic]], [[Leonardo Valencia]], [[Binyavanga Wainaina]] (not present due to illness), [[Frank Westerman]], [[Wu Ming]], and more. WALTIC 2008 honorary guest was poet [[Tomas Tranströmer]]. "I am glad to participate in the WALTIC congress because it is devoted to democracy, and the act of reading is a very good example of pure democracy in action," said writer Philip Pullman when asked about his participation in the 2008 congress.
Chairman of The Swedish Writers' Union and President of WALTIC 2008: Mats Söderlund. Program Committee: [[Gabriella Håkansson]] and [[Henrik C. Enbohm]].
== WALTIC Resolution ==
During WALTIC 2008 a resolution was adopted stating that: "''Literature is a source of knowledge with the strength to empower entire populations''", hence underlining that "''Literacy, freedom of expression and authors' rights are keys to the never-ending pursuit of truth, for the development of societies based on democratic and humanitarian values as well as for the individual aspiring to express his or her unique knowledge and experience''", and moreover, that "''Increasing literacy is essential to improvement of welfare and democratic processes, and to the safeguarding of human rights''." The resolution also noted that "''Safeguarding freedom of expression makes it possible for both the ordinary citizen and decision makers to better understand the world around them and thus to make informed decisions''". (The WALTIC Resolution can be read in full at www.waltic.com)
== References ==
Article in [[Ny Tid]] [http://www.nytid.fi/arkiv/artikelnt-684-7118.html]
Article in [[Dagens Nyheter]] [http://www.dn.se/dnbok/tusen-forfattare-mots-i-stockholm-1.596159]
WALTIC Resolution [https://web.archive.org/web/20100325211256/http://www.waltic.com/]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Waltic}} [[Category:International conferences in Sweden]] [[Category:Swedish culture]] [[Category:Biennial events]]
[[sv:Sveriges Författarförbund#WALTIC]]

revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]] archives
revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = William Ansel Kinney |image = William Ansel Kinney, in the Hawaiian Military Commission of 1895.jpg |caption = William Ansel Kinney in 1895 |birth_date = {{birth date|1860|10|16}} |birth_place = [[Honolulu, Hawaii]] |death_date = c. 1930 |death_place = |parents = |spouse = Alice Vaughan McBryde |alma_mater=[[University of Michigan]] |occupation = Lawyer |nationality = [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]
[[United States]] }} '''William Ansel Kinney''' (1860–1930) was a lawyer and politician in the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]], through the [[Republic of Hawaii]] and into the [[Territory of Hawaii]]. ==Family== William Ansel Kinney was born October 16, 1860, in [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]]. His father was William Kinney, who was born April 15, 1832, in [[Chebogue, Nova Scotia]].{{cite book |title=Sons of the American Revolution. Hawaii Society Yearbook |editor= [[William DeWitt Alexander]] |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k0sCAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA45 |year=1897 |page=45}} His uncle [[Joseph Robbins Kinney]] (1839–1919) was a member of the [[House of Commons of Canada]]. His father came to the [[Hawaiian Islands]] in the 1850s and married his mother Caroline Dailey (died March 25, 1897) on July 6, 1857. His father then married up to three different [[native Hawaiian]] women, having many other children by them. For example, half-brother William Kihapi{{okina}}ilani Kinney (1868–1953) married Mary Francesca Vierra, and their son Ernest Kaipoleimanu Kinney (1906–1987) married Esther Kauikeaulani Ka{{okina}}ulili and had daughter [[Rubellite Kawena Kinney Johnson]], who became a Hawaiian historian.{{cite web |title= John Keny, d. 1693, Milton, MA |work= DNA test results |author= Georgia Kinney Bopp |date= June 4, 2010 |url= http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~gkbopp/KINNEY/Research/LINES2/73491.htm |accessdate= August 15, 2010 }} The youngest half-sibling was [[Ray Kinney]], born in [[Hilo]] September 26, 1900, who became a popular musician and composer. His father managed the [[sugarcane]] [[Sugar plantations in Hawaii|plantation]] at [[Honomu, Hawaii]] and died June 3, 1915.{{cite web |title= Nick Hayes & Sue Drake - root and branch |work= Rootsweb |url = http://wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=hayes-drake&id=I17983 |accessdate= August 14, 2010 }} ==Law career== Kinney attended [[Royal School (Hawaii)|Royal School]] and later [[Punahou School]] 1874–1877 and worked as a clerk in a law office. He graduated from law school at the [[University of Michigan]] in 1883.{{cite book |author=Charles I. York |title=History of law class of 1883 of Michigan University |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yCPiAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA68 |year=1883 |page=68}} He married Alice Vaughan McBryde on August 16, 1893 in Honolulu.{{cite web |url= http://www.ulukau.org/gsdl2.7/cgi-bin/algene?e=q-0algene&a=d&c=algene&d=D10-000042 |title=Marriage record |work=state archives digital collections |publisher=state of Hawaii |accessdate= August 14, 2010 }} His first law partner was [[Arthur P. Peterson]]. In 1887 he became partners with [[William Owen Smith]] and [[Lorrin A. Thurston]].{{cite book |title=Hawaiian Kingdom 1874-1893, the Kalakaua Dynasty |author= [[Ralph Simpson Kuykendall]] |url= http://www.ulukau.org/elib/cgi-bin/library?c=kingdom3&l=en |volume=3 |publisher= University of Hawaii Press |year= 1967 |isbn= 978-0-87022-433-1 |page= 347 }} In 1887 he was elected to the [[legislature of the Hawaiian Kingdom]] as a representative from [[Hawaii (island)|Hawai{{okina}}i island]].{{cite web |url= http://archives1.dags.hawaii.gov/gsdl/collect/governme/index/assoc/HASH016c/205230a5.dir/Kinney,%20William%20A.jpg |title= Kinney, William Ansel office record |work=state archives digital collections |publisher=state of Hawaii |accessdate= August 14, 2010 }} During the summer of 1887, he helped draft the [[1887 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii]], called the "Bayonet Constitution" because King [[Kalākaua]] was forced to sign it. The government headed by [[Walter M. Gibson]] was forced to resign and was replaced by one including Thurston in the cabinet.{{cite book |author=David W. Forbes |title=Hawaiian national bibliography, 1780-1900 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jAuzOipG26YC&pg=PA232 |year=2003 |publisher=University of Hawaii Press |isbn=978-0-8248-2636-9 |pages=232–233}} [[File:Trial of 1895 Counter-Revolution in Hawaii.jpg|thumb|right|alt=men at table in military uniforms, others standing|The 1895 trial in former [[Iolani Palace|{{okina}}Iolani Palace]] throne room; Kinney seated at far right]] He moved to [[Salt Lake City, Utah]], about 1891 and practiced law there.{{cite news |title= Mrs. Caroline D. Kinney Passed Away March 25:She was the Mother of William A. Kinney, Once a Lawyer of This City |newspaper= The Salt Lake herald |location= Salt Lake City, Utah |date= April 9, 1897 |url= http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058130/1897-04-09/ed-1/seq-5/ |accessdate= August 16, 2010 }} After the 1893 [[overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii]], he was met by some of his former partners, including Thurston, as they visited the [[United States]] to lobby for annexation in February.{{cite news |title= To Plead Hawaii's Cause; The Commissioners Have Arrived in Washington. They are to Meet the Secretary of State To-day |newspaper= [[New York Times]] |date= February 4, 1893 |url= https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1893/02/04/109261702.pdf |format= pdf |accessdate= August 14, 2010 }} After [[Liliuokalani|Queen Lili{{okina}}uokalani]] was arrested in January 1895 following the failed [[1895 Counter-Revolution in Hawaii|1895 rebellion]] against the [[Republic of Hawaii]], Kinney was selected as [[Judge Advocate]] (with honorary rank of Captain) to prosecute her in a military trial in her former throne room at [[Iolani Palace|{{okina}}Iolani Palace]]. She was convicted of [[misprision of treason]].{{cite news |title= Abdication of Queen Liliuokalan: Safety at the Price of a Kingdom, of Little Moment Now for the Cause of the Royalists is a Lost Cause |newspaper= The Morning Call |location= San Francisco |date= February 7, 1895 |url= http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn94052989/1895-02-07/ed-1/seq-1/ |accessdate= August 14, 2010 }} On March 7 he traveled to [[San Francisco]] to press charges against the people accused of shipping arms to the rebels.{{cite news |title= More Exiles from Honolulu: The ex-Queen Refuses to Leave Her Residence While Serving the Term of Her Sentence |newspaper= [[New York Times]] |date= March 15, 1895 |url= https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1895/03/15/105977994.pdf |format= pdf |accessdate= August 14, 2010 }} On May 5, 1897, he was selected for another commission to lobby for annexation to the United States. He traveled to [[Washington, DC]], and in reply to the Queen's protest was quoted with a comment that might sound racist by modern standards regarding native Hawaiians and Chinese and Japanese interests:
Their future is one of two things, to pass under Asiatic or Anglo-Saxon control. If Asiatics dominate, the native must become a coolie, for certainly he cannot expect to be better off than the rank and file of the dominant race....It is a choice between the status of a white American laborer and that of an Asiatic coolie laborer. The white race, if Asiatics absorb Hawaii, can get out to their own country.{{cite news |title= Reply to Liliuokalani: Special Commissioner Kinney Discusses the Ex-Queen's Protest |newspaper= [[New York Times]] |date= June 20, 1897 |url= https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1897/06/20/105947014.pdf |format= pdf |accessdate= August 14, 2010 }}
This time US Secretary of State [[John Sherman (politician)|John Sherman]] signed a treaty with Kinney, Thurston, and [[New Hampshire]] lawyer Francis March Hatch on June 16, 1897.{{cite news|author= Clarence Johnson |editor= Otis Grant Hammond |title= Francis March Hatch |work= The Granite state monthly |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YchYAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA65 |date= August 1897 |publisher=Granite Monthly Company |pages= 63–70 }}{{cite web |work= The [[Morgan Report]] |url= http://morganreport.org/mediawiki/index.php?title=1897_Annexation_Treaty |title= 1897 Hawaii Annexation Treaty |accessdate= August 14, 2010 }} The Treaty of Annexation was unanimously adopted by the Senate of the Republic of Hawaii on September 9, 1897. The U.S. Senate passed it by vote of 42–21, the U.S. House of Representatives passed it by vote of 209–91, and President William McKinley signed it on July 7, 1898. On his return, he heard that physician Jared Knapp Smith, brother of his former law partner who was then attorney general, had been killed on September 24, 1897. It was suspected to be in retaliation for ordering patients suspected of [[leprosy]] to exile in [[Kalaupapa Leprosy Settlement and National Historical Park|Kalaupapa]], which had ignited the [[Leper War on Kaua'i]] four years earlier. Kinney sailed to [[Kauai|Kaua{{okina}}i]] island and was appointed special prosecutor. A native Hawaiian suspect Kapea was arrested, tried on November 13, 1897, found guilty of first degree murder, and hanged on April 11, 1898.{{cite news |hdl= 10524/564 |title= Murder, a Trial, a Hanging: The Kapea Case of 1897–1898 |work= Hawaiian Journal of History |publisher=Hawaii Historical Society |volume= 42 |author1= Esther Kwon Arinaga |author2= Caroline Axtell Garrett |year= 2008 |pages= 201–230 }} In August 1900 he sued a newspaper editor for [[libel]].{{cite news |title= A Criminal Libel Suit: Attorney Sues E. S. Gill Editor of Republican |newspaper= The Hawaiian Gazette |location= Honolulu |date= August 17, 1900 |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1900-08-17/ed-1/seq-2/ |accessdate=2013-02-23}} In May 1901 he was sentenced to prison for contempt of court, but pardoned by [[Sanford B. Dole]].{{cite news |title= Executive Interference with Judicial Rights: Three Lawyers Sent to Prison for Contempt of Court Given Immediate Pardons |newspaper= The Honolulu Republican |date= May 26, 1901 |url= http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047165/1901-05-26/ed-1/seq-1/ |page= 1 |accessdate= August 14, 2010 }} His partnership was then called "Kinney, McClanahan & Cooper", including [[Henry Ernest Cooper]] who had chaired the [[Committee of Safety (Hawaii)|Committee of Safety]] in 1893 and E. B. McClanahan. At least one of their cases, "Territory of Hawaii vs. Cotton Brothers & Company" of 1904 went to the [[United States Supreme Court]].{{cite book |author=United States Supreme Court |title=United States Supreme Court records and briefs |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=riArAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA8-PA20 |year=1907 |pages=27–177}} By 1906 the firm replaced Cooper with S. H. Derby. In June 1909 he represented the [[Hawaiian Sugar Planters' Association]] in a conflict during a strike by Japanese workers.{{cite news |title= Japanese Charge Burglary: Hawaiian Strike Leaders Retort to Prosecution for Conspiracy to Murder |newspaper= [[New York Times]] |date= June 19, 1909 |url= https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1909/06/19/101740162.pdf |format= pdf |accessdate= August 16, 2010 }} Despite his role in her trial, on November 1909 Kinney served as an attorney for deposed Queen Lili{{okina}}uokalani in a [[United States Court of Claims]] case "Liliuokalani v. The United States".{{cite wikisource|title=Liliuokalani v. The United States|author=[[United States Court of Claims]]|date=November 20, 1909}} His partners are listed as Sidney Miller Ballou and Anderson. The case claimed that the Queen was due compensation for the taking of the [[crown land]]s of the kingdom. In the decision known as 45 Ct. Cl. 418 (1910), the case was dismissed on May 16, 1910. The issue continues to be controversial, known as the [[ceded lands]] issue. Kinney's grand-niece Rubellite Kawena Kinney Johnson filed a similar case 80 years later which was also dismissed on appeal.{{cite web |title= Rubellite Kinney Johnson, Plaintiff-appellant, v. the United States |work= United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit. - 976 F.2d 747 |date= August 10, 1992 |url= http://cases.justia.com/us-court-of-appeals/F2/976/747/48008/|accessdate= August 16, 2010 }} [[File:Kinney political cartoon 1912.jpg|thumb|right|Political cartoon of 1912 depicting Kinney on the shoulder of a governor going after sugarcane plantation interests]] Kinney grew disenchanted with the territorial government. Instead of the labor reform he had hoped for, he considered the sugarcane plantation owners, known as the "[[Big Five (Hawaii)|Big Five]]", an [[oligopoly]] which continued to exploit cheap workers. By 1912 he joined with congressional delegate [[Jonah Kūhiō Kalaniana'ole|Jonah Kūhiō Kalaniana{{okina}}ole]] in public opposition to appointed [[governor of Hawaii|Territorial Governor]] [[Walter F. Frear]].{{cite book |author= United States Congress House Committee on the Territories |title=Hearing before the Committee on the Territories of the House of Representatives on leasing of land in Hawaii: Statements of B.G. Rivenburgh, Hon. Geo. H. Fairchild, Hon. W.A. Kinney, and A.S. Tuttle, Esq. January 20 and February 8, 1912 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gGU-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1 |year=1912| publisher= Government Printing Office }} Kūhiō was the only territorial-wide elected official, although with no direct power. Earlier a firmly conservative Republican, Kinney switched to the [[Democratic Party of Hawaii]]. When Democratic President [[Woodrow Wilson]] was elected in 1912, Kinney lobbied for a strong reformer to be swiftly appointed as governor. Kinney was attacked in the Hawaii press (controlled by Republicans), and characterized as proposing a [[carpetbagger]] for governor. Frear said "Mr. Kinney would do better if he stayed here and worked for the best interests of the Territory, instead of going to Washington and complaining."{{cite news |title=Governor from Mainland Best! So Say Kinney, the Man Kuhio Left to Represent Him at Washington; Attorney's Outbreak Does Not Stir Planters, Though They Are Ones Attacked |newspaper= The Hawaiian Gazette |location= Honolulu |date= February 23, 1912 |page= 2 |url= http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1912-02-23/ed-1/seq-2/ |accessdate= August 20, 2010 }} Although the local party supported [[Lincoln Loy McCandless]], it was not until November 1913 that Wilson appointed [[Lucius E. Pinkham]]. Pinkham had not lived in Hawaii and but had represented plantation owners and other industrialists earlier.{{cite news |hdl= 10524/373 |title= The Controversial Appointment of Lucius Eugene Pinkham, Hawaii's First Democratic Governor |work= Hawaiian Journal of History |publisher=Hawaii Historical Society |volume= 17 |author= [[H. Brett Melendy]] |year= 1983 |pages= 185–208 }} By the end of 1913 he was living in [[California]], where he filed suit against [[Alexander & Baldwin]], one of the Big Five who were agents for his in-laws' McBryde sugarcane plantation.{{cite news |title= Shareholders of M'Bryde in Session: Meeting of Sugar Plantation Company is Called to Take Action on Charges of Mismanagement Against Alexander & Baldwin, Agents of the Company, by W. A. Kinney |newspaper= The Hawaiian Gazette |location= Honolulu |date=December 12, 1913 |page= 2 |url= http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1913-12-12/ed-1/seq-2/ |accessdate= August 20, 2010 }} In 1928 Kinney sued Utah Senator [[Reed Smoot]] and [[Mormon]] leader [[Heber Grant]], accusing them of trying to prevent his book from being published.{{cite news |title= Mormons Sued for Damages: Head of Church and U.S. Senator Smoot Charged with Conspiracy |newspaper= Sarasota Herald |date= May 20, 1928 |url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=n98cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=H2QEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1356,926551&dq=william+a+kinney&hl=en |accessdate= August 14, 2010 }}{{cite news |title= Sues Senator Smoot and Head of Mormons; Los Angeles Man Also Names 21 Concerns for "Conspiracy and Harassment" |newspaper= [[New York Times]] |date= February 4, 1893 |url= http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00D14FE395C177A93C2AB178ED85F4C8285F9 |accessdate= August 15, 2010 }} He died sometime after 1930 in California. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |author1= William Ansel Kinney |author2= Arthur Tuttle |title=In the matter of the establishment of a federal harbor on the island of Kauai, Territory of Hawaii |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=yZHlHAAACAAJ |year=1912 }} * {{cite book |author=Neil Thomas Proto |title=The rights of my people: Liliuokalani's enduring battle with the United States, 1893-1917 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LSPbRywQ3WQC |year=2009 |publisher=Algora Publishing |isbn=978-0-87586-720-5}} * {{cite book |author=William A. Kinney |title=Hawaii's capacity for self-government all but destroyed |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=00dCAAAAIAAJ |year=1927 |publisher=F.L. Jensen |location= Salt Lake City, Utah }} ==External links== * {{Internet Archive author |sname=William Ansel Kinney |sopt=t}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kinney, William Ansel}} [[Category:1860 births]] [[Category:1930 deaths]] [[Category:Kingdom of Hawaii politicians]] [[Category:Members of the Kingdom of Hawaii House of Representatives]] [[Category:Hawaii lawyers]] [[Category:Punahou School alumni]] [[Category:People associated with the Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii]] [[Category:University of Michigan Law School alumni]] [[Category:Royal School (Hawaii) alumni]]
